item.title: 'Ma Rainey's Black Bottom' Is A Parting Gift From Actor Chadwick Boseman
item.description: Boseman died of cancer in 2020, not long after he finished shooting this adaptation of August Wilson's play. His final screen performance — as a troubled trumpet player — ranks among his best.
item.content:encoded: Boseman died of cancer in 2020, not long after he finished shooting this adaptation of August Wilson's play. His final screen performance — as a troubled trumpet player — ranks among his best.
item.dc:creator: Justin Chang

item.title: After A Swarm Of Bugs, Microsoft And Sony Offer Refunds On 'Cyberpunk 2077'
item.description: Sony also pulled the game from its online store. Developer CD Projekt Red delayed Cyberpunk several times for tweaks, but players on consoles, particularly older models, reported bugs and glitches.
item.content:encoded:
Sony also pulled the game from its online store. Developer CD Projekt Red delayed Cyberpunk several times for tweaks, but players on consoles, particularly older models, reported bugs and glitches.

(Image credit: CD Projekt Red)
item.dc:creator: Andrew Limbong

item.title: Andrew Bird: Hark!
item.description: Musician Andrew Bird shares how composer Vince Guaraldi's soundtrack for A Charlie Brown Christmas inspired his new holiday album Hark! Then he performs a song off the album called Christmas in April.
item.content:encoded:
Musician Andrew Bird shares how composer Vince Guaraldi's soundtrack for A Charlie Brown Christmas inspired his new holiday album Hark! Then he performs a song off the album called Christmas in April.

(Image credit: Reuben Cox/Provided by the artist)

item.title: Slang Game
item.description: Jonathan Coulton's kids Theo and Eleanor help their dad and Ophira Eisenberg translate and navigate the latest teen slang. It's "lit!" Are the kids still saying that?
item.content:encoded: Jonathan Coulton's kids Theo and Eleanor help their dad and Ophira Eisenberg translate and navigate the latest teen slang. It's "lit!" Are the kids still saying that?

item.title: NPR Christmas Carols
item.description: Three out of six women who work at NPR named Carol make their Ask Me Another debut as they lend their vocals in a music parody game that changes the lyrics to Paul McCartney's Wonderful Christmastime.
item.content:encoded: Three out of six women who work at NPR named Carol make their Ask Me Another debut as they lend their vocals in a music parody game that changes the lyrics to Paul McCartney's Wonderful Christmastime.

item.title: Real Or Fake Holiday Album
item.description: Composers Robert Lopez and Kristen Anderson Lopez try to spot fake holiday album titles in this speed round. Hold onto your novelty elf hats because William Shatner's Shatner Claus... is real!
item.content:encoded: Composers Robert Lopez and Kristen Anderson Lopez try to spot fake holiday album titles in this speed round. Hold onto your novelty elf hats because William Shatner's Shatner Claus... is real!

item.title: Check-In: Office Holiday Parties
item.description: Host Ophira Eisenberg and house musician Jonathan Coulton discuss office holiday parties, and regret they can't raid the NPR supply closet this year.
item.content:encoded: Host Ophira Eisenberg and house musician Jonathan Coulton discuss office holiday parties, and regret they can't raid the NPR supply closet this year.

item.title: Sourdough Starter Recipes That Aren't Bread
item.description: Early in the pandemic, lots of new bakers turned to sourdough, But in case you are somehow sick of that classic sourdough loaf, baker and blogger Bryan Ford has some ideas.
item.content:encoded: Early in the pandemic, lots of new bakers turned to sourdough, But in case you are somehow sick of that classic sourdough loaf, baker and blogger Bryan Ford has some ideas.

item.title: 'Ma Rainey's Black Bottom' Shines A Light On August Wilson's Vision
item.description: The late August Wilson's first Broadway hit, Ma Rainey's Black Bottom, has been adapted for the screen, starring Viola Davis and Chadwick Boseman in his final film role.
item.content:encoded:
The late August Wilson's first Broadway hit, Ma Rainey's Black Bottom, has been adapted for the screen, starring Viola Davis and Chadwick Boseman in his final film role.

(Image credit: Jeff Kravitz/FilmMagic, Inc)

item.description: 2020 has given us an unprecedented number of new Christmas movies centering on characters who used to be, at most, sidekicks in holiday fare.

item.title: In 'Funny Boy,' A Young Sri Lankan Gay Man Comes Of Age As Ethnic Tensions Explode
item.description: Deepa Mehta's new film, Funny Boy, is Canada's Oscar submission. It's being distributed by Ava DuVernay's company and premieres on Netflix. It's based on the novel by Shyam Selvadurai.
item.content:encoded:

item.title: 'Late Night' Comic Amber Ruffin On Her New Show — And Telling Jokes Seth Meyers Can't
item.description: The Late Night writer and performer hosts The Amber Ruffin Show on NBC's streaming service, Peacock. "I've earned (hopefully) enough grace to do whatever I want," she says of her new hosting gig.
item.content:encoded: The Late Night writer and performer hosts The Amber Ruffin Show on NBC's streaming service, Peacock. "I've earned (hopefully) enough grace to do whatever I want," she says of her new hosting gig.

item.title: Christopher Nolan On 'Tenet' And Time, 'The Most Cinematic Of Subjects'
item.description: The director, producer and writer discusses the making of Tenet, directing actors who are moving and talking forwards and backwards, and why he's drawn to exploring time in his films.

The director, producer and writer discusses the making of Tenet, directing actors who are moving and talking forwards and backwards, and why he's drawn to exploring time in his films.

item.title: In 'I Came As A Shadow,' Georgetown's John Thompson Offers Some Surprising Moments
item.description: The Hall of Fame basketball coach, who died in August, leaves us with the private thoughts of a public man, one who both raged against racial injustice and embraced chances to make things better.
item.content:encoded:
The Hall of Fame basketball coach, who died in August, leaves us with the private thoughts of a public man, one who both raged against racial injustice and embraced chances to make things better.

item.title: The Best Gifts I Received Before Top Surgery
item.description: Metal straws, a flash drive full of downloaded bootleg concerts, and other small blessings.

item.title: Festive Holiday Recipes for 2020
item.description: How to make a single gingerbread person, to be enjoyed with coffee, or all by itself, because it is ?perfectly fine ?alone?.

item.title: Problems with TV in 2033
item.description: Reality TV is news, news is comedy, and sitcoms are fantasy.
item.dc:creator: Annah Feinberg, Gina Young

item.description: New cartoons from the magazine.

item.title: Betsy DeVos Warns That Biden Will Pick Education Secretary with Background in Education
item.description: “For the past four years, I have worked tirelessly to keep our schools free from education,” she said.

item.description: You know that thing from “Men in Black” that you wave in front of people’s faces, and it makes them forget what happened?

item.title: A Sampling of the Best Shouts of 2020
item.media:keywords: Humor, Donald Trump, Instagram, Online Dating, Anthony Fauci
item.description: There’s been a lot of laugh-crying ’round these parts. Thanks to the ever-adaptive minds of the super-funny, it was not just permanent cry-crying.

item.title: Some 2020 “Feel Good” Holiday Movies
item.description: After disconnecting from an agonizing family Zoom call, soothe your nerves by turning on the TV and watching a fake Zoom call that goes slightly better.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Si

item.title: Lessons from the Unpresidential Transition to Apply to Your Love Life
item.description: Do not attempt to hide out on a golf course from lovers you’ve scorned. We can all see you.

item.title: Daily Cartoon Slide Show
item.description: Daily Cartoon Slide Show.

item.title: Stocking Up in Case of Emergency: A Pantry Prepped for Quarantine
item.description: A can of human touch, a container of relaxed time with family—some of these supplies may come in handy during lockdown.

item.title: Seven Signs Your Neighbor’s Dog Is Totally Into You
item.description: Here’s how to tell if that nearby canine really cares.

item.title: “Antiques Roadshow”: 2021
item.description: The world has changed, but everyone’s favorite heirloom-focussed TV show is here to stay!

item.title: This Whole Time, Instead of a Meeting . . .
item.description: This could’ve been an e-mail, a message in a bottle, a burning bush, or nothing at all.
item.dc:creator: Laura Mishkin

item.title: How to Draw the Rats and Pigeons from Your Nightmares
item.description: A zoology major turned cartoonist on the pigeon mustache that has scientists baffled, and how to make a cartoon mouse look like a jaded Broadway star.

item.title: A New Yorker Cartoonist on Why Weddings Make Great Jokes
item.description: Carolita Johnson demonstrates how to draw wedding dresses and explains why no one invites her to weddings anymore.

item.title: How to Make Your Anxiety Funny
item.description: Some thoughts keep you awake for hours, wondering why you’d say something so horrible to your dental hygienist when you don’t even have an idea of what her stance on composting is.

item.title: Fred Armisen, Patton Oswalt, and Angela Kinsey Battle Threats Real and Imagined
item.description: The comedians play duelling neighbors in this adaptation of George Saunders’s short story “Adams.”

item.title: The Influence of the Anti-Vaccine Movement
item.media:keywords: Coronavirus, Vaccines, Misinformation, Pandemics, Donald Trump
item.description: The virologist Peter Hotez discusses the spread of misinformation about the COVID-19 vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Isaac Chotiner

item.title: The Republican Rift in Georgia, and Season’s Greetings from Ian Frazier
item.description: The Georgia G.O.P. is at war with itself, as its U.S. Senate seats are up for grabs in critical runoff elections. And citizens in Nigeria are rising up against a brutal police unit.
item.category: Podcast / The New Yorker Radio Hour

item.title: Elton John On Music, Addiction And Family: 'I'm Proud Of Who I Am Now'
item.description: In 2019, John told Fresh Air that his father's early misgivings about his chosen career became a source of motivation: "He gave me the determination to make something of myself."
item.content:encoded: In 2019, John told Fresh Air that his father's early misgivings about his chosen career became a source of motivation: "He gave me the determination to make something of myself."

item.title: Without Resources, Vaccine Rollout Could 'Fall At The Last Hurdle,' Journalist Warns
item.description: Atlantic writer Ed Yong says the COVID-19 vaccination program will be the most complicated the U.S. has ever attempted: "It's going to be a slow process, and there are a lot of possible roadblocks."
item.content:encoded:

item.title: Dust-To-Digital Producers On Curating And Showcasing 'Harry Smith B-Sides'
item.description: Music producers Lance and April Ledbetter talk about curating their new anthology, which collects the flip sides of the 78s Smith chose for his 1952 Anthology of American Folk Music.
item.content:encoded: Music producers Lance and April Ledbetter talk about curating their new anthology, which collects the flip sides of the 78s Smith chose for his 1952 Anthology of American Folk Music.

item.title: MC And Actor Riz Ahmed Embraces A New Kind Of Role In 'Sound Of Metal'
item.description: Ahmed plays a drummer who loses his hearing in Sound of Metal. To prepare for the role, he immersed himself in deaf culture — an experience that changed the way he thought about communication.
item.content:encoded:
Ahmed plays a drummer who loses his hearing in Sound of Metal. To prepare for the role, he immersed himself in deaf culture — an experience that changed the way he thought about communication.

(Image credit: Amazon Studios)
item.dc:creator: Terry Gross

item.title: A Year Like No Other: Ken Tucker Picks 10 Albums That Made An Art Of Escapism
item.description: The pandemic, along with unprecedented political and social upheaval, created a year in which listeners sought to be transported. Enter these 10 albums. At the top of the list: X's Alphabetland.
item.content:encoded:
The pandemic, along with unprecedented political and social upheaval, created a year in which listeners sought to be transported. Enter these 10 albums. At the top of the list: X's Alphabetland.

(Image credit: Gareth Cattermole/Getty Images for dcp)
item.dc:creator: Ken Tucker

item.title: Remembering John Le Carré, British Spy Turned Best-Selling Novelist
item.description: Le Carré, who died Dec. 12, worked for MI5 and MI6 early in his career and later drew on that experience in thrillers like The Spy Who Came in from the Cold. Originally broadcast in 1989 and 2017.
item.content:encoded: Le Carré, who died Dec. 12, worked for MI5 and MI6 early in his career and later drew on that experience in thrillers like The Spy Who Came in from the Cold. Originally broadcast in 1989 and 2017.
item.dc:creator: Terry Gross

item.title: Fresh Air Weekend: Kate Winslet; Loudon Wainwright III And Vince Giordano
item.description: Winslet says she wanted to portrays a same-sex love story "wtihtout fear or secrecy" in Ammonite. Loudon Wainwright III and Vince Giordano play from the "Great American Songbook."
item.content:encoded:
Winslet says she wanted to portrays a same-sex love story "wtihtout fear or secrecy" in Ammonite. Loudon Wainwright III and Vince Giordano play from the "Great American Songbook."

(Image credit: Neon)

item.title: 'Bad Behavior By People In High Office': Rachel Maddow On The Lessons Of Spiro Agnew
item.description: Richard Nixon's first vice president resigned amid charges of bribery and tax evasion. Maddow and Mike Yarvitz revisit Agnew's story in the podcast (and now book) Bag Man. Originally broadcast in '19.
item.content:encoded: Richard Nixon's first vice president resigned amid charges of bribery and tax evasion. Maddow and Mike Yarvitz revisit Agnew's story in the podcast (and now book) Bag Man. Originally broadcast in '19.
item.dc:creator: Terry Gross

item.title: An Immigrant Family Is Reunited After 17 Years In The Sweetly Moving 'Farewell Amor'
item.description: The film opens in an airport where a man greets the wife and daughter he hasn't seen in years. Farewell Amor is a deeply empathetic story about the struggles and anxieties of one immigrant family.
item.content:encoded:
The film opens in an airport where a man greets the wife and daughter he hasn't seen in years. Farewell Amor is a deeply empathetic story about the struggles and anxieties of one immigrant family.

(Image credit: IFC Films)
item.dc:creator: Justin Chang

item.title: 'It Is Roiling Him': Reporter Maggie Haberman Unpacks Trump's Refusal To Admit He Lost
item.description: "[Trump] can't handle the concept of the label 'loser,' " Haberman says. "He has never before encountered a problem that he couldn't sue away through the court system or spin away."
item.content:encoded:
"[Trump] can't handle the concept of the label 'loser,' " Haberman says. "He has never before encountered a problem that he couldn't sue away through the court system or spin away."

(Image credit: Brendan Smialowski/AFP via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Terry Gross

item.title: Lawyer Combats America's 'Huge Crisis' Of Mass Incarceration
item.description: Brittany Barnett works on behalf of people serving harsh sentences as a result of the war on drugs. Nine of her clients have been granted clemency. Her new memoir is A Knock at Midnight.
item.content:encoded: Brittany Barnett works on behalf of people serving harsh sentences as a result of the war on drugs. Nine of her clients have been granted clemency. Her new memoir is A Knock at Midnight.
item.dc:creator: Terry Gross

item.title: Remembering Chuck Yeager, Pilot Who Broke The Sound Barrier
item.description: The legendary aviator, who died Dec. 7, served as a fighter pilot in World War II. Later, as a test pilot, he was the first person to fly faster than the speed of sound. Originally broadcast in 1988.
item.content:encoded: The legendary aviator, who died Dec. 7, served as a fighter pilot in World War II. Later, as a test pilot, he was the first person to fly faster than the speed of sound. Originally broadcast in 1988.
item.dc:creator: Terry Gross

item.title: Cameras, Chaos And Cognac: How Bob Gruen Photographed The Spirit Of Rock 'N' Roll
item.description: Gruen has photographed countless rock stars, including the Rolling Stones, Chuck Berry, Tina Turner and John Lennon. "For me, rock 'n' roll is all about freedom," he says.
item.content:encoded:
Gruen has photographed countless rock stars, including the Rolling Stones, Chuck Berry, Tina Turner and John Lennon. "For me, rock 'n' roll is all about freedom," he says.

(Image credit: Bob Gruen/Bob Gruen Studios)
item.dc:creator: Dave Davies

item.title: Chadwick Boseman's Last Movie, 'Ma Rainey's Black Bottom,' Reviewed
item.description: August Wilson's award-winning play, Ma Rainey's Black Bottom, about a recording session in 1927 Chicago, comes to the screen with Viola Davis and Chadwick Boseman in his final role.

item.title: Difficulties Of Movie Production During The Pandemic
item.description: Actor Tom Cruise was caught on tape admonishing the crew for breaking safety protocols on the set of Mission: Impossible 7. NPR discusses the difficulties of moviemaking during the pandemic.

item.title: 'Assassins' Explores What Happened In Killing Of Kim Jong Un's Half Brother
item.description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks with filmmaker Ryan White about his documentary Assassins, which explores the killing of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un's half brother at a Malaysian airport.

item.title: 'Grease,' 'Shrek' And A Record Number Of Women Directors Join National Film Registry
item.description: Every year, the Library of Congress adds 25 movies to the National Film Registry to be preserved for posterity. This year's list includes a record number of female directors and directors of color.
item.content:encoded:
Every year, the Library of Congress adds 25 movies to the National Film Registry to be preserved for posterity. This year's list includes a record number of female directors and directors of color.

item.description: NPR's Lulu Garcia-Navarro speaks with Emily Blunt about her new movie, set in Ireland, Wild Mountain Thyme.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Lulu Garcia-Navarro speaks with Emily Blunt about her new movie, set in Ireland, Wild Mountain Thyme.

item.title: FKA twigs Sues Shia LaBeouf, Accusing Him Of Domestic Abuse
item.description: The musician FKA twigs has filed suit against her ex-boyfriend, actor Shia LaBeouf, alleging that he had physically and mentally abused her. She says another ex-girlfriend has made similar claims.
item.content:encoded:
The musician FKA twigs has filed suit against her ex-boyfriend, actor Shia LaBeouf, alleging that he had physically and mentally abused her. She says another ex-girlfriend has made similar claims.

(Image credit: Valerie Macon/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Christopher Nolan Calls Warner Bros.' Shift To Streaming New Movies 'A Great Danger'
item.description: In an interview with NPR, the blockbuster director said the studio's decision to stream movies on HBO Max on the day of their release will hurt the people who work in the movie industry.
item.content:encoded:
